author: pedro7g5

text: @tinyknott When they said the simulation would end if you failed to beat Fatman, I took it to mean that it would literally end because the entire place would have been blown to smithereens. I think this game would have been a lot less confusing if you swapped the word "simulation" with the term "training excercise".
author: Blaquecell

text:
@AlphaFirefly 
Well, the nanobots worked just fine for MGS4, they just should have left vamp to die in MGS2 instead of trying to make some sensible explanation to how he can survive a headshot with a sniper, and still survive. No nanobots can repair anything of that magnitude. A headshot with a sniper will have sent ~10% of the brain flying out of the skull, at least, and destroyed a whole lot more. The only things nanobots could do then is to keep him alive in a vegetative state...
author: Einar

text:
@Blaquecell 
Well, they claim that if you had "failed at taking down fatman, the simulation would end there". This implies that it was supposed to be a routine simulation, maybe with real boss figures, but in the end, fake. Then somehow, it turns out the actions done by solidus and his gang were for real, which contradicts the previous claim. And Snake wasn't meant to be there at all. So yeah, you do have it right, but there's something icky with the whole simulation/not a simulation story.
author: Einar
Einar

text: @tinyknott Good points, although MGS2 wasn't a "virtual" simulation per se, as all of the people in the story that Raiden personally encountered were definitely real (except for AI Campbell and AI Rose, of course). It's just that all of the people were purposely placed in their roles by the Patriots to see if a situation similar to Shadow Moses could create a soldier as good as Snake. The monkey wrench in their plan was the unexpected arrival of the real Solid Snake.
author: Blaquecell
Einar

text:
cont 4
This is what I find so enthralling with MGS2. It pushes so many opinions, so many views into you at the moment you're the most confused, and makes you wonder what is true, what is not. And this is very parallel to the media of today. To be able to calmly assess the situation and find out what's true on your own rather than being told so. I doubt they could have done this if you had snake, because he's just too badass to be confused.
(raiden was made to make the game appeal to girls btw)
author: Einar

text:
cont nr3
Now, there's a whole lot of other things going on as well (some supernatural that's just absurd) But the important thing is that Metal Gear Arsenal (the rig) is the embodiment of a governmental censorship of free speech. It is what allows the patriots to rule without anyone ever being able to get the word out about it. This is what is interesting. Should you be allowed to say and listen to anything, or should there be control? Should some people control what side of the story is told?
author: Einar

text:
cont. nr 2
gear rex's that were stationed there. You fight a few before the virus destroys all advanced systems, including the rex's. Solidus has now lost his advantage, and has therefore got to proceed without killing you.

metal gear Arsenal not a weapon of destruciton. Arsenal is a gigantic internet filter. It checks all communication, and controls it. This is what the Patriots are using to stay in power. Solidus intends to destroy this, and bring down the Patriots, whatever the cost.
author: Einar

text:
continued
Raiden doesn't.

At the end, it turns out it all has been a virtual simulation to train him, gone wrong from actual interference from the villains (yes, it doesn't make sense. First they say the enemy was a simulation, then they don't. I think they were using acid when writing this bit). Snake and Solidus were not meant to be in there. The virus made by otagon cripples the simulation, allowing everyone to escape, in this time, Solidus has gained control of the rig. and the metal
author: Einar
Einar

author: Armagibson

text:
Personally, I am really glad that they used Raiden as the main character in the game. Why? Because if it had been snake, they couldn't have pushed the whole "barrage the main character with opinions and influences" ending the way they did. Having a "blank slate" allowed them to try to influence him and choose a different approach.

Simply put: The ending would have been far more straight forward and philosophically inferior if they hadn't had Raiden as the main character.
author: Einar

text:
I saw this game for PS2 today in a second hand video games store and I bought it immediately. 
But I don't own a Playstation. 
I said to myself: But one beautiful day I will play it, and enjoy the game and this wonderful music, that every gamer loves.

Thank you for this masterpiece of music that makes me smile and think about this awesomeness I'm going to enjoy soon.
Simply: Thank you.

author: Tom Jansen

text:
My understanding is, if you distribute it freely, it goes under the fair use policy. The trouble is, since you can't market it, you can't pay back your expenses.

And because of that, you can't hire workers so easily. You end out making a low budget game. Maybe something like a rom. Good luck on doing Halo and GTA in rom form without severely reworking it.

Fortunately, low budget games can be awesome. And we can always dream.

text:
Love that song.
I used to fire up my PS2 every morning before I went to school to play this intro.

The ending is so damn patriotic that I can't listen to it without imagining some huge battle, whether it be a comic-book styled super-human one, realistic Middle-East one, or just some fuckin' huge MGS one.
